title: Kinh Phạm võng
blurb: While others may praise or criticize the Buddha, they tend to focus on trivial details. The Buddha presents an analysis of 62 kinds of wrong view, seeing through which one becomes detached from meaningless speculations.

title: Kinh Sa-môn quả
blurb: The newly crowned King Ajātasattu is disturbed by the violent means by which he achieved the crown. He visits the Buddha to find peace of mind, and asks him about the benefits of spiritual practice. This is one of the greatest literary and spiritual texts of early Buddhism.

title: Kinh Ambaṭṭha (A-ma-trú)
blurb: A young brahmin student attacks the Buddha’s family, but is put in his place.

title: Kinh Soṇadaṇḍa (Chủng Ðức)
blurb: A reputed brahmin visits the Buddha, despite the reservations of other brahmins. They discuss the true meaning of a brahmin, and the Buddha skillfully draws him around to his own point of view.

title: Kinh Kūṭadanta (Cứu-la-đàn-đầu)
blurb: A brahmin wishes to undertake a great sacrifice, and asks for the Buddha’s advice. The Buddha tells a legend of the past, in which a king is persuaded to give up violent sacrifice, and instead to devote his resources to supporting the needy citizens of his realm. However, even such a beneficial and non-violent sacrifice pales in comparison to the spiritual sacrifice of giving up attachments.

title: Kinh Mahāli
blurb: The Buddha explains to a diverse group of lay people how the results of meditation depend on the manner of development.

title: Kinh Jāliya
blurb: This discourse is mostly quoted by the Buddha in the previous.

title: Kinh Ca-diếp Sư tử hống
blurb: The Buddha is challenged by a naked ascetic on the topic of spiritual austerities. He points out that it is quite possible to perform all kinds of austere practices without having any inner purity of mind.

title: Kinh Poṭṭhapāda (Bố-sá-bà-lâu)
blurb: The Buddha discusses with a wanderer the nature of perception and how it evolves through deeper states of meditation. None of these, however, should be identified with a self or soul.

title: Kinh Subha (Tu-bà)
blurb: Shortly after the Buddha’s death, Venerable Ānanda is invited to explain the core teachings.

title: Kinh Kevaddha (Kiên Cố)
blurb: The Buddha refuses to perform miracles, explaining that this is not the right way to inspire faith. He goes on to tell the story of a monk whose misguided quest for answers led him as far as Brahmā.

title: Kinh Lohicca (Lô-hi-gia)
blurb: A brahmin has fallen into the idea that there is no point in trying to offer spiritual help to others. The Buddha goes to see him, and persuades him of the genuine benefits of spiritual teaching.

title: Kinh Tevijjā (Tam minh)
blurb: A number of brahmins are discussing the true path to Brahmā. Contesting the claims to authority based on the Vedas, the Buddha insists that only personal experience can lead to the truth.

title: Kinh Ðại bổn
blurb: The Buddha teaches about the six Buddhas of the past, and tells a lengthy account of one of those, Vipassī.

title: Kinh Ðại duyên
blurb: Rejecting Venerable Ānanda’s claim to easily understand dependent origination, the Buddha presents a complex and demanding analysis, revealing hidden nuances and implications of this central teaching.

title: Kinh Ðại Bát-Niết-Bàn
blurb: The longest of all discourses, this extended narrative tells of the events surrounding the Buddha’s death. Full of vivid and moving details, it is an ideal entry point into knowing the Buddha as a person, and understanding how the Buddhist community coped with his passing.

title: Kinh Ðại Thiện Kiến vương
blurb: An elaborate story of a past life of the Buddha as a legendary king who renounced all to practice meditation.

title: Kinh Xa-ni-sa
blurb: Beginning with an account of the fates of disciples who had recently passed away, the scene shifts to a discussion of Dhamma held by the gods.

title: Kinh Ðại Ðiển Tôn
blurb: A minor deity informs the Buddha of the conversations and business of the gods.

title: Kinh Ðại hội
blurb: When deities from all realms gather in homage to the Buddha, he gives a series of verses describing them. These verses, which are commonly chanted in Theravadin countries, give one of the most detailed descriptions of the deities worshiped at the the time of the Buddha.

title: Kinh Ðế-thích sở vấn
blurb: After hearing a love song from a god of music, the Buddha engages in a deep discussion with Sakka on the conditioned origin of attachment and suffering.

title: Kinh Ðại Niệm xứ
blurb: The Buddha details the seventh factor of the noble eightfold path, mindfulness meditation. This discourse is essentially identical to MN 10, with the addition of an extended section on the four noble truths derived from MN 141.

title: Kinh Tệ-túc
blurb: This is a long and entertaining debate between a monk and a skeptic, who went to elaborate and bizarre lengths to prove that there is no such thing as an afterlife. The discourse contains a colorful series of parables and examples.

title: Kinh Ba-lê
blurb: When Sunakkhatta threatens to disrobe, the Buddha is unimpressed. Rejecting showy displays of asceticism or wondrous powers, he demonstrates his pre-eminence.

title: Kinh Ưu-đàm-bà-la sư tử hống
blurb: This discourse gives a specially good example of dialog between religions. The Buddha insists that he is not interested to make anyone give up their teacher or practices, but only to help people let go of suffering.

title: Kinh Chuyển luân Thánh vương Sư tử hống
blurb: In illustration of his dictum that one should rely on oneself, the Buddha gives a detailed account of the fall of a kingly lineage of the past, and the subsequent degeneration of society. This process, however, is not over, as the Buddha predicts that eventually society will fall into utter chaos. But far in the future, another Buddha, Metteyya, will arise in a time of peace and plenty.

title: Kinh Khởi thế nhân bổn
blurb: In contrast with the brahmin’s self-serving mythologies of the past, the Buddha presents an account of evolution that shows how human choices are an integral part of the ecological balance, and how excessive greed destroys the order of nature.

title: Kinh Tự hoan hỷ
blurb: Shortly before he passes away, Venerable Sāriputta visits the Buddha and utters a moving eulogy of his great teacher.

title: Kinh Thanh tịnh
blurb: Following the death of Nigaṇṭha Nātaputta, the leader of the Jains, the Buddha emphasizes the stability and maturity of his own community. He encourages the community to come together after his death and recite the teachings in harmony.

title: Kinh Tướng
blurb: This presents the brahmanical prophecy of the Great Man, and explains the 32 marks in detail. This discourse contains some of the latest and most complex verse forms in the canon.

title: Kinh Giáo thọ Thi-ca-la-việt
blurb: The Buddha encounters a young man who honors his dead father by performing rituals. The Buddha recasts the meaningless rites in terms of virtuous conduct. This is the most detailed discourse on ethics for lay people.

title: Kinh A-sá-nang-chi
blurb: Mighty spirits hold a congregation, and warn the Buddha that, since not all spirits are friendly, the mendicants should learn verses of protection.

title: Kinh Phúng tụng
blurb: The Buddha encourages Venerable Sāriputta to teach the mendicants, and he offers an extended listing of Buddhist doctrines arranged in numerical sequence.

title: Kinh Thập thượng
blurb: This is similar to the previous, but with a different manner of exposition. These two discourses anticipate some of the methods of the Abhidhamma.

title: Lobhasutta
blurb: Abandon greed, and you’re guaranteed non-return.

title: Dosasutta
blurb: Abandon aversion, and you’re guaranteed non-return.

title: Mohasutta
blurb: Abandon delusion, and you’re guaranteed non-return.

title: Kodhasutta
blurb: Abandon anger, and you’re guaranteed non-return.

title: Makkhasutta
blurb: Abandon contempt, and you’re guaranteed non-return.

title: Mānasutta
blurb: Abandon conceit, and you’re guaranteed non-return.

title: Sabbapariññāsutta
blurb: When the mind, cleansed of passion for the All, abandons it, you are capable of putting an end to suffering.

title: Mānapariññāsutta
blurb: When the mind, cleansed of passion for conceit, abandons it, you are capable of putting an end to suffering.

title: Lobhapariññāsutta
blurb: When the mind, cleansed of passion for greed, abandons it, you are capable of putting an end to suffering.

title: Dosapariññāsutta
blurb: When the mind, cleansed of passion for aversion, abandons it, you are capable of putting an end to suffering.

title: Mohapariññāsutta
blurb: When the mind, cleansed of passion for delusion, abandons it, you are capable of putting an end to suffering.

title: Kodhapariññāsutta
blurb: When the mind, cleansed of passion for anger, abandons it, you are capable of putting an end to suffering.

title: Makkhapariññāsutta
blurb: When the mind, cleansed of passion for contempt, abandons it, you are capable of putting an end to suffering.

title: Avijjānīvaraṇasutta
blurb: Hindered by the hindrance of ignorance, people go wandering and transmigrating on for a long, long time.

title: Taṇhāsaṁyojanasutta
blurb: Fettered with the fetter of craving, beings go wandering and transmigrating on for a long, long time.

title: Paṭhamasekhasutta
blurb: Appropriate attention as the prime internal factor to help those in training.

title: Dutiyasekhasutta
blurb: Friendship with admirable people as the prime external factor to help those in training.

title: Saṁghabhedasutta
blurb: Schism in the Sangha leads to the detriment and unhappiness of many beings, both human and divine.

title: Saṁghasāmaggīsutta
blurb: Concord in the Sangha leads to the welfare and happiness of many beings, both human and divine.

title: Paduṭṭhacittasutta
blurb: Corrupt-mindedness leads to rebirth in the planes of deprivation.

title: Pasannacittasutta
blurb: Clear-mindedness leads to rebirth in a heavenly world.

title: Mettasutta
blurb: “Acts of merit” is a synonym for what is blissful, desirable, pleasing, endearing, charming. The Buddha recalls the results he himself has experienced from doing meritorious deeds.

title: Ubhayatthasutta
blurb: Heedfulness with regard to skillful qualities keeps both kinds of benefit secure: benefit in this live and benefit in lives to come.

title: Aṭṭhipuñjasutta
blurb: In this course of transmigrating, one person would leave behind a heap of bones as large as a mountain—if there were someone to collect the bones and the collection were not destroyed.

title: Musāvādasutta
blurb: A person who tells a deliberate lie is capable of any evil deed.

title: Dānasutta
blurb: If you knew, as the Buddha did, the results of giving and sharing, you wouldn’t eat without having shared.

title: Mettābhāvanāsutta
blurb: Goodwill far outshines all other ways of making merit.

title: Dukkhavihārasutta
blurb: Not guarding the doors of the sense faculties and knowing no moderation in food leads to suffering in this life and the next.

title: Sukhavihārasutta
blurb: Guarding the doors of the sense faculties and knowing moderation in food leads to ease in this life and the next.

title: Tapanīyasutta
blurb: Two things that cause remorse.

title: Atapanīyasutta
blurb: Two things that cause lack of remorse.

title: Paṭhamasīlasutta
blurb: A person of evil habits and evil views goes to hell.

title: Dutiyasīlasutta
blurb: A person of auspicious habits and auspicious views goes to heaven.

title: Ātāpīsutta
blurb: To lack ardency and compunction makes you incapable of unbinding.

title: Paṭhamajananakuhanasutta
blurb: The holy life is lived for the purpose of restraint and abandoning.

title: Dutiyajananakuhanasutta
blurb: The holy life is lived for the purpose of direct knowledge and full comprehension.

title: Somanassasutta
blurb: A sense of urgency and appropriate exertion bring ease here-and-now, and lead to the ending of the defilements.

title: Vitakkasutta
blurb: Two thoughts that often occur to the Buddha as he delights in non-ill will and seclusion.

title: Desanāsutta
blurb: Two Dhamma sequences: see evil as evil, and become released from it.

title: Vijjāsutta
blurb: Ignorance leads to lack of conscience and prudence.

title: Paññāparihīnasutta
blurb: The rewards of noble discernment.

title: Sukkadhammasutta
blurb: Conscience and prudence safeguard the world.

title: Ajātasutta
blurb: The existence of an unfabricated dimension allows for the escape from conditions.

title: Nibbānadhātusutta
blurb: Two unbinding properties: with fuel remaining and with no fuel remaining.

title: Paṭisallānasutta
blurb: Live enjoying aloofness, delighting in aloofness, inwardly committed to awareness-tranquility, not neglecting jhāna, endowed with clear-seeing insight, and frequenting empty buildings.

title: Sikkhānisaṁsasutta
blurb: Live with the trainings as your reward, with discernment uppermost, with release the essence, and with mindfulness the governing principle.

title: Jāgariyasutta
blurb: Be wakeful, mindful, alert, centered, sensitive, clear, and calm. And there you should, at the appropriate times, see clearly into skillful mental qualities.

title: Āpāyikasutta
blurb: Two types of behavior that lead to hell.

title: Diṭṭhigatasutta
blurb: How those with vision differ from those who adhere to craving for rebirth and those who slip past into craving to be annihilated.

title: Mūlasutta
blurb: Three roots of what is unskillful.

title: Dhātusutta
blurb: Three properties: form, formlessness, cessation.

title: Paṭhamavedanāsutta
blurb: Three feelings.

title: Dutiyavedanāsutta
blurb: How the three types of feeling should be viewed.

title: Paṭhamaesanāsutta
blurb: Three searches: for sensuality, for rebirth, for a holy life.

title: Dutiyaesanāsutta
blurb: Three searches: for sensuality, for rebirth, for a holy life.

title: Paṭhamaāsavasutta
blurb: Three defilements.

title: Dutiyaāsavasutta
blurb: Three defilements.

title: Taṇhāsutta
blurb: Three cravings.

title: Māradheyyasutta
blurb: Three qualities that lead beyond Māra’s domain.

title: Puññakiriyavatthusutta
blurb: Three grounds for meritorious activity.

title: Cakkhusutta
blurb: Three eyes: the eye of flesh, the divine eye, and the eye of discernment.

title: Indriyasutta
blurb: The noble attainments described in terms of three faculties.

title: Addhāsutta
blurb: Three time periods and the importance of comprehending signs.

title: Duccaritasutta
blurb: Three kinds of misconduct.

title: Sucaritasutta
blurb: Three kinds of good conduct.

title: Soceyyasutta
blurb: Three kinds of cleanliness: bodily, verbal, and mental.

title: Moneyyasutta
blurb: Three forms of sagacity: bodily, verbal, and mental.

title: Paṭhamarāgasutta
blurb: One whose passion, aversion, and delusion are abandoned is freed from Māra’s power.

title: Dutiyarāgasutta
blurb: To abandon passion, aversion, and delusion is like crossing over the dangers of the ocean.

title: Micchādiṭṭhikasutta
blurb: The Buddha reports having seen, for himself, beings reborn in planes of deprivation in line with their wrong views and evil actions.

title: Sammādiṭṭhikasutta
blurb: The Buddha reports having seen, for himself, beings reborn in good destinations in line with their right views and good actions.

title: Nissaraṇiyasutta
blurb: Three properties for escape: from sensuality, from form, and from whatever is fabricated and dependently co-arisen.

title: Santatarasutta
blurb: Formless phenomena are more peaceful than forms; cessation, more peaceful than formless phenomena.

title: Puttasutta
blurb: Three types of sons and daughters (when compared to their parents): of heightened birth, of similar birth, and of lowered birth.

title: Avuṭṭhikasutta
blurb: Three types of people: one like a cloud without rain, one who rains locally, and one who rains everywhere.

title: Sukhapatthanāsutta
blurb: Aspiring to three forms of bliss, wise people should guard their virtue.

title: Bhidurasutta
blurb: This body falls apart; consciousness is subject to fading; all acquisitions are inconstant, sufferingful, subject to change.

title: Dhātusosaṁsandanasutta
blurb: Like attracts like. It’s in accordance with their properties—either low or admirable—that beings come together and associate with one another.

title: Parihānasutta
blurb: Three things lead to the falling away of a monk in training.

title: Vitakkasutta
blurb: Three kinds of unskillful thinking.

title: Sakkārasutta
blurb: The dangers of letting your mind be overcome by the fact that you either receive offerings or don’t receive offerings.

title: Devasaddasutta
blurb: Three occasions on which devas give voice to joy over the behavior of human beings.

title: Pañcapubbanimittasutta
blurb: Five omens that appear when a deva is about to pass away, and the encouragement that other devas give at that time.

title: Bahujanahitasutta
blurb: Three people who appear for the benefit of the world.

title: Asubhānupassīsutta
blurb: The rewards of focusing on the foulness of the body, of establishing mindfulness of breathing to the fore, and of focusing on the inconstancy of all conditions.

title: Dhammānudhammapaṭipannasutta
blurb: Practicing the Dhamma in accordance with the Dhamma.

title: Andhakaraṇasutta
blurb: Three kinds of unskillful thinking; three kinds of skillful thinking.

title: Antarāmalasutta
blurb: Three inside stains.

title: Devadattasutta
blurb: Conquered by three forms of false Dhamma, Devadatta was incurably doomed to deprivation.

title: Aggappasādasutta
blurb: Three supreme objects of confidence: the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Saṅgha.

title: Jīvikasutta
blurb: Why reasonable people take up the life of alms-going, and the dangers that lie in wait if they do not train their minds.

title: Saṅghāṭikaṇṇasutta
blurb: To see the Dhamma is to see the Buddha and to be close to him, even when physically far away.

title: Aggisutta
blurb: The three fires: of passion, aversion, and delusion.

title: Upaparikkhasutta
blurb: On having consciousness neither externally scattered and diffused, nor internally positioned.

title: Kāmūpapattisutta
blurb: Three ways in which devas obtain sensual pleasures.

title: Kāmayogasutta
blurb: The yoke of sensuality and the yoke of rebirth.

title: Kalyāṇasīlasutta
blurb: Admirable virtue, admirable qualities, and admirable discernment defined.

title: Dānasutta
blurb: Two kinds of gifts, sharing, and assistance: in material things and in Dhamma.

title: Tevijjasutta
blurb: The three knowledges that characterize a brahman in the Buddha’s sense of the word.

title: Brāhmaṇadhammayāgasutta
blurb: The Buddha as doctor; the monks as his heirs in Dhamma, not in material things.

title: Sulabhasutta
blurb: The four basic requisites are easy to gain and blameless. To be content with them is a factor of the contemplative life.

title: Āsavakkhayasutta
blurb: For one knowing and seeing the four noble truths, there is the ending of suffering.

title: Samaṇabrāhmaṇasutta
blurb: To see the four noble truths is to count as a true contemplative.

title: Sīlasampannasutta
blurb: The rewards of associating with those who genuinely count as admirable friends.

title: Taṇhuppādasutta
blurb: Where a monk’s craving takes birth.

title: Sabrahmakasutta
blurb: Mother and father as the Brahmās and first teachers of their children.

title: Bahukārasutta
blurb: The reciprocal ways in which monks and lay supporters benefit one another.

title: Kuhasutta
blurb: Monks who are and who are not the Buddha’s true followers.

title: Nadīsotasutta
blurb: An extended metaphor for the dangers of “going with the flow.”

title: Carasutta
blurb: What it means to have ardency and compunction.

title: Sampannasīlasutta
blurb: When one is consummate in virtue, what more is to be done?

title: Lokasutta
blurb: The qualities that entitle the Buddha to be called Tathāgata.

title: Tam Quy
blurb: The three refuges formula

title: Thập Giới
blurb: The ten precepts of a novice mendicant

title: Ba Mươi Hai Phần
blurb: The thirty-two parts of the body for reflection

title: Nam Tử Hỏi Ðạo
blurb: A list of ten doctrinal factors

title: Kinh Ðiềm Lành
blurb: A list of the types of skillful behavior that give blessings and protection.

title: Kinh Châu Báu
blurb: The many treasures to be found in the Triple Gem.

title: Kinh Ngoài Bức Tường
blurb: The Supreme Buddha explains how to share merit with past relatives.

title: Kinh Bảo Tàng
blurb: Merit is the only sure investment

title: Kinh Lòng Từ
blurb: The practice of developing universal goodwill: the practices that form a foundation for the practice, the attitude of universal goodwill itself, and the steps that lead from goodwill to awakening.

title: Kinh Pháp Môn Căn Bản
blurb: The Buddha examines how the notion of a permanent self emerges from the process of perception. A wide range of phenomena are considered, embracing both naturalistic and cosmological dimensions. An unawakened person interprets experience in terms of a self, while those more advanced have the same experiences without attachment.

title: Kinh Tất cả các lậu hoặc
blurb: The diverse problems of the spiritual journey demand a diverse range of responses. Rather than applying the same solution to every problem, the Buddha outlines seven methods of dealing with defilements, each of which works in certain cases.

title: Kinh thừa tự Pháp
blurb: Some of the Buddha’s students inherit from him only material profits and fame. But his true inheritance is the spiritual path, the way of contentment. Venerable Sāriputta explains how by following the Buddha’s example we can experience the fruits of the path.

title: Kinh Sợ hãi khiếp đảm
blurb: The Buddha explains the difficulties of living in the wilderness, and how they are overcome by purity of conduct and meditation. He recounts some of the fears and obstacles he faced during his own practice.

title: Kinh Không uế nhiễm
blurb: The Buddha’s chief disciples, Sāriputta and Moggallāna, use a simile of a tarnished bowl to illustrate the blemishes of the mind and conduct. They emphasize how the crucial thing is not so much whether there are blemishes, but whether we are aware of them.

title: Kinh Ước nguyện
blurb: According to the Buddha, careful observance of ethical precepts is the foundation of all higher achievements in the spiritual life.

title: Kinh Ví dụ tấm vải
blurb: The many different kinds of impurities that defile the mind are compared to a dirty cloth. When the mind is clean we find joy, which leads to states of higher consciousness. Finally, the Buddha rejects the Brahmanical notion that purity comes from bathing in sacred rivers.

title: Kinh Ðoạn giảm
blurb: The Buddha differentiates between peaceful meditation and spiritual practices that encompass the whole of life. He lists forty-four aspects, which he explains as “effacement”, the wearing away of conceit.

title: Kinh Chánh tri kiến
blurb: Venerable Sāriputta gives a detailed explanation of right view, the first factor of the noble eightfold path. At the prompting of the other mendicants, he approaches the topic from a wide range of perspectives.

title: Kinh Niệm xứ
blurb: Here the Buddha details the seventh factor of the noble eightfold path, mindfulness meditation. This collects many of the meditation teachings found throughout the canon, especially the foundational practices focusing on the body, and is regarded as one of the most important meditation discourses.

title: Tiểu kinh Sư tử hống
blurb: The Buddha declares that only those following his path can genuinely experience the four stages of awakening. This is because, while much is shared with other systems, none of them go so far as to fully reject all attachment to the idea of a self.

title: Ðại kinh Sư tử hống
blurb: A disrobed monk, Sunakkhatta, attacks the Buddha’s teaching because it merely leads to the end of suffering. The Buddha counters that this is, in fact, praise, and goes on to enumerate his many profound and powerful achievements.

title: Ðại kinh Khổ uẩn
blurb: Challenged to show the difference between his teaching and that of other ascetics, the Buddha points out that they speak of letting go, but do not really understand why. He then explains in great detail the suffering that arises from attachment to sensual stimulation.

title: Tiểu kinh Khổ uẩn
blurb: A lay person is puzzled at how, despite their long practice, they still have greedy or hateful thoughts. The Buddha explains the importance of absorption meditation for letting go such attachments. But he also criticizes self-mortification, and recounts a previous dialog with Jain ascetics.

title: Kinh Tư lượng
blurb: Venerable Moggallāna raises the topic of admonishment, without which healthy community is not possible. He lists a number of qualities that will encourage others to think it worthwhile to admonish you in a constructive way.

title: Kinh Tâm hoang vu
blurb: The Buddha explains various ways one can become emotionally cut off from one’s spiritual community.

title: Kinh Khu rừng
blurb: While living in the wilderness is great, not everyone is ready for it. The Buddha encourages meditators to reflect on whether one’s environment is genuinely supporting their meditation practice, and if not, to leave.

title: Kinh Mật hoàn
blurb: Challenged by a brahmin, the Buddha gives an enigmatic response on how conflict arises due to proliferation based on perceptions. Venerable Kaccāna draws out the detailed implications of this in one of the most insightful passages in the entire canon.

title: Kinh Song tầm
blurb: Recounting his own experiences in developing meditation, the Buddha explains how to understand harmful and harmless thoughts, and how to go beyond thought altogether.

title: Kinh An trú tầm
blurb: In a practical meditation teaching, the Buddha describes five different approaches to stopping thoughts.

title: Kinh Ví dụ cái cưa
blurb: A discourse full of vibrant and memorable similes, on the importance of patience and love even when faced with abuse and criticism. The Buddha finishes with the simile of the saw, one of the most memorable similes found in the discourses.

title: Kinh Ví dụ con rắn
blurb: One of the monks denies that prohibited conduct is really a problem. The monks and then the Buddha subject him to an impressive dressing down. The Buddha compares someone who understands only the letter of the teachings to someone who grabs a snake by the tail, and also invokes the famous simile of the raft.

title: Kinh Gò mối
blurb: In a curious discourse laden with evocative imagery, a deity presents a riddle to a mendicant, who seeks an answer from the Buddha.

title: Kinh Trạm xe
blurb: Venerable Sāriputta seeks a dialog with an esteemed monk, Venerable Puṇṇa Mantāniputta, and they discuss the stages of purification.

title: Kinh Bẫy mồi
blurb: The Buddha compares getting trapped by Māra with a deer getting caught in a snare, illustrating the ever more complex strategies employed by hunter and hunted.

title: Kinh Thánh cầu
blurb: This is one of the most important biographical discourses, telling the Buddha’s experiences from leaving home to realizing awakening. Throughout, he was driven by the imperative to fully escape from rebirth and suffering.

title: Tiểu kinh Dụ dấu chân voi
blurb: The Buddha cautions against swift conclusions about a teacher’s spiritual accomplishments, comparing it to the care a tracker would use when tracking elephants. He presents the full training of a monastic.

title: Ðại kinh Dụ dấu chân voi
blurb: Sāriputta gives an elaborate demonstration of how, just as any footprint can fit inside an elephant’s, all the Buddha’s teaching can fit inside the four noble truths. This offers an overall template for organizing the Buddha’s teachings.

title: Ðại kinh Thí dụ Lõi cây
blurb: Following the incident with Devadatta, the Buddha cautions the mendicants against becoming complacent with superficial benefits of spiritual life and points to liberation as the true heart of the teaching.

title: Tiểu kinh Dụ lõi cây
blurb: Similar to the previous. After the incident with Devadatta, the Buddha cautions the mendicants against becoming complacent and points to liberation as the true heart of the teaching.

title: Tiểu kinh Rừng sừng bò
blurb: The Buddha comes across three mendicants practicing diligently and harmoniously, and asks them how they do it. Reluctant to disclose their higher attainments, they explain how they deal with the practical affairs of living together. But when pressed by the Buddha, they reveal their meditation attainments.

title: Ðại kinh Rừng sừng bò
blurb: Several senior mendicants, reveling in the beauty of the night, discuss what kind of practitioner would adorn the park. They take their answers to the Buddha, who praises their answers, but gives his own twist.

title: Ðại kinh Người chăn bò
blurb: For eleven reasons a cowherd is not able to properly look after a herd. The Buddha compares this to the spiritual growth of a mendicant.

title: Tiểu kinh Người chăn bò
blurb: Drawing parallels with a cowherd guiding his herd across a dangerous river, the Buddha presents the various kinds of enlightened disciples who cross the stream of transmigration.

title: Tiểu kinh Saccaka
blurb: Saccaka was a debater, who challenged the Buddha to a contest. Despite his bragging, the Buddha is not at all perturbed at his attacks.

title: Ðại kinh Saccaka
blurb: In a less confrontational meeting, the Buddha and Saccaka discuss the difference between physical and mental development. The Buddha gives a long account of the various practices he did before awakening, detailing the astonishing lengths he took to mortify the body.

title: Tiểu kinh Ðoạn tận ái
blurb: Moggallāna visits the heaven of Sakka, the lord of gods, to see whether he really understands what the Buddha is teaching.

title: Ðại kinh Ðoạn tận ái
blurb: To counter the wrong view that a self-identical consciousness transmigrates from one life to the next, the Buddha teaches dependent origination, showing that consciousness invariably arises dependent on conditions.

title: Ðại kinh Xóm ngựa
blurb: The Buddha encourages the mendicants to live up to their name, by actually practicing in a way that meets or exceeds the expectations people have for renunciants.

title: Tiểu kinh Xóm ngựa
blurb: The labels of being a spiritual practitioner don’t just come from external trappings, but from sincere inner change.

title: Kinh Sàleyyaka
blurb: The Buddha explains to a group of brahmins the conduct leading to rebirth in higher or lower states, including detailed explanations of the ten core practices which lay people should undertake, and which also form the basis for liberation.

title: Kinh Veranjaka
blurb: Similar to the previous. The Buddha explains the conduct leading to rebirth in higher or lower states, including detailed explanations of the ten core practices.

title: Ðại kinh Phương quảng
blurb: A series of questions and answers between Sāriputta and Mahākoṭṭhita, examining various subtle and abstruse aspects of the teachings.

title: Tiểu kinh Phương quảng
blurb: The layman Visākha asks the nun Dhammadinnā about various difficult matters, including some of the highest meditation attainments. The Buddha fully endorses her answers.

title: Tiểu kinh Pháp hành
blurb: The Buddha explains how taking up different practices may have harmful or beneficial results. The memorable simile of the creeper shows how insidious temptations can be.

title: Ðại kinh Pháp hành
blurb: While we all want to be happy, we often find the opposite happens. The Buddha explains why.

title: Kinh Tư sát
blurb: While some spiritual teachers prefer to remain in obscurity, the Buddha not only encouraged his followers to closely investigate him, but gave them a detailed and demanding method to do so.

title: Kinh Kosambiya
blurb: Despite the Buddha’s presence, the monks of Kosambi fell into a deep and bitter dispute. The Buddha taught the reluctant monks to develop love and harmony, reminding them of the state of peace that they sought.

title: Kinh Phạm Thiên cầu thỉnh
blurb: The Buddha ascends to a high heavenly realm where he engages in a cosmic contest with a powerful divinity, who had fallen into the delusion that he was eternal and all-powerful.

title: Kinh Hàng ma
blurb: Māra, the trickster and god of death, tried to annoy Moggallāna. He not only failed but was subject to a stern sermon warning of the dangers of attacking the Buddha’s disciples.

title: Kinh Kandaraka
blurb: The Buddha discusses mindfulness meditation with lay practitioners. Contrasting the openness of animals with the duplicity of humans, he explains how to practice in a way that causes no harm to oneself or others.

title: Kinh Bát thành
blurb: Asked by a householder to teach a path to freedom, Venerable Ānanda explains no less than eleven meditative states that may serve as doors to the deathless.

title: Kinh Hữu học
blurb: The Buddha is invited by his family, the Sakyans of Kapilavatthu, to inaugurate a new community hall. He invites Venerable Ānanda to explain in detail the stages of spiritual practice for a lay trainee.

title: Kinh Potaliya
blurb: When Potaliya got upset at being referred to as “householder”, the Buddha quizzed him as to the true nature of attachment and renunciation.

title: Kinh Jìvaka
blurb: The Buddha’s personal doctor, Jīvaka, hears criticisms of the Buddha’s policy regarding eating meat, and asks him about it.

title: Kinh Ưu-ba-ly
blurb: The Buddha disagrees with a Jain ascetic on the question of whether physical or mental deeds are more important. When he hears of this, the Jain disciple Upāli decides to visit the Buddha and refute him, and proceeds despite all warnings.

title: Kinh Hạnh con chó
blurb: Some ascetics in ancient India undertook extreme practices, such as a vow to behave like an ox or a dog. The Buddha meets two such individuals, and is reluctantly pressed to reveal the kammic outcomes of such practice.

title: Kinh Vương tử Vô Úy
blurb: The leader of the Jains, Nigaṇṭha Nātaputta, gives his disciple Prince Abhaya a dilemma to pose to the Buddha, supposing that this will show his weakness. Things don’t go quite as planned.

title: Kinh Nhiều cảm thọ
blurb: The Buddha resolves a disagreement on the number of kinds of feelings that he taught, pointing out that different ways of teaching are appropriate in different contexts, and should not be a cause of disputes. He goes on to show the importance of pleasure in developing higher meditation.

title: Kinh Không gì chuyển hướng
blurb: The Buddha teaches a group of uncommitted householders how to use a rational reflection to arrive at practices and principles that are guaranteed to have a good outcome, even if we don’t know all the variables.

title: Kinh Giáo giới La-hầu-la ở rừng Āmala
blurb: Using the “object lesson” of a cup of water, the Buddha explains to his son, Rāhula, the importance of telling the truth and reflecting on one’s motives.

title: Ðại kinh Giáo giới La-hầu-la
blurb: The Buddha tells Rāhula to meditate on not-self, which he immediately puts into practice. Seeing him, Venerable Sāriputta advises him to develop breath meditation, but the Buddha suggests a wide range of different practices first.

title: Tiểu kinh Màlunkyà
blurb: A monk demands that the Buddha answer his metaphysical questions, or else he will disrobe. The Buddha compares him to a man struck by an arrow, who refuses treatment until he can have all his questions about the arrow and the archer answered.

title: Ðại kinh Màlunkyà
blurb: A little baby has no wrong views or intentions, but the underlying tendency for these things is still there. Without practicing, they will inevitably recur.

title: Kinh Bhaddàli
blurb: A monk refuses to follow the rule forbidding eating after noon, but is filled with remorse and forgiven.

title: Kinh Ví dụ Con chim cáy
blurb: Again raising the rule regarding eating, but this time as a reflection of gratitude for the Buddha in eliminating things that cause complexity and stress. The Buddha emphasizes how attachment even to little things can be dangerous.

title: Kinh Càtumà
blurb: After dismissing some unruly monks, the Buddha is persuaded to relent, and teaches them four dangers for those gone forth.

title: Kinh Nalakapāna
blurb: Those who practice do so not because they are failures, but because they aspire to higher freedom. When he speaks of the attainments of disciples, the Buddha does so in order to inspire.

title: Kinh Gulisàni
blurb: A monk comes down to the community from the wilderness, but doesn’t behave properly. Venerable Sāriputta explains how a mendicant should behave, whether in forest or town.

title: Kinh Kìtàgiri
blurb: A third discourse that presents the health benefits of eating in one part of the day, and the reluctance of some mendicants to follow this.

title: Kinh Dạy Vacchagotta về Tam Minh
blurb: The Buddha denies being omniscient, and sets forth the three higher knowledges that form the core of his awakened insight.

title: Kinh Dạy Vacchagotta về Lửa
blurb: Refusing to take a stance regarding useless metaphysical speculations, the Buddha illustrates the spiritual goal with the simile of a flame going out.

title: Ðại kinh Vaccaghotta
blurb: In the final installment of the “Vacchagotta trilogy”, Vacchagotta lets go his obsession with meaningless speculation, and asks about practice.

title: Kinh Trường Trảo
blurb: Deftly outmaneuvering an extreme skeptic, the Buddha discusses the outcomes of belief and disbelief. Rather than getting stuck in abstractions, he encourages staying close to the feelings one experiences.

title: Kinh Māgandiya
blurb: Accused by a hedonist of being too negative, the Buddha recounts the luxury of his upbringing, and his realization of how little value there was in such things. Through renunciation he found a far greater pleasure.

title: Kinh Sandaka
blurb: Venerable Ānanda teaches a group of wanderers how there are many different approaches to the spiritual life, many of which lead nowhere.

title: Ðại kinh Sakaludāyin
blurb: Unlike many teachers, the Buddha’s followers treat him with genuine love and respect, since they see the sincerity of his teaching and practice.

title: Kinh Samanamandikà
blurb: A wanderer teaches that a person has reached the highest attainment when they keep four basic ethical precepts. The Buddha’s standards are considerably higher.

title: Tiểu kinh Sakuludayi (Thiện sanh Ưu đà di)
blurb: A wanderer teaches his doctrine of the “highest splendor” but is unable to give a satisfactory account of what that means. The Buddha memorably compares him to someone who is in love with an idealized women who he has never met.

title: Kinh Vekhanassa
blurb: Starting off similar to the previous, the Buddha goes on to explain that one is not converted to his teaching just because of clever arguments, but because you see in yourself the results of the practice.

title: Kinh Ghaṭikāra
blurb: The Buddha relates an unusual account of a past life in the time of the previous Buddha, Kassapa. At that time he was not interested in Dhamma, and had to be forced to go see the Buddha. This discourse is important in understanding the development of the Bodhisattva doctrine.

title: Kinh Raṭṭḥapāla
blurb: A wealthy young man, Raṭṭhapāla, has a strong aspiration to go forth, but has to prevail against the reluctance of his parents. Even after he became a monk, his parents tried to persuade him to disrobe. The discourse ends with a moving series of teachings on the fragility of the world.

title: Kinh Makhàdeva
blurb: A rare extended mythic narrative, telling of an ancient kingly lineage and their eventual downfall.

title: Kinh Madhurà
blurb: In Madhurā, towards the north-eastern limit of the Buddha’s reach during his life, King Avantiputta asks Venerable Mahākaccāna regarding the brahmanical claim to be the highest caste.

title: Kinh Vương tử Bồ-đề
blurb: Admitting that he used to believe that pleasure was to be gained through pain, the Buddha explains how his practice showed him the fallacy of that idea.

title: Kinh Angulimàla
blurb: Ignoring warnings, the Buddha ventures into the domain of the notorious killer Aṅgulimāla and succeeds in converting him to the path of non-violence. After becoming a monk Aṅgulimāla still suffered for his past deeds, but only to a small extent. He uses his new commitment to non-violence to help a woman in labor.

title: Kinh Ái sanh
blurb: A rare glimpse into the marital life of King Pasenadi, and how he is led to the Dhamma by his Queen, the incomparable Mallikā. She confirms the Buddha’s teaching that our loved ones bring us sorrow; but that’s not something a husband, father, and king wants to hear.

title: Kinh Bàhitika
blurb: King Pasenadi takes a chance to visit Venerable Ānanda, where he asks about skillful and unskillful behavior, and what is praised by the Buddha. He offers Ānanda a valuable cloth in gratitude.

title: Kinh Pháp trang nghiêm
blurb: King Pasenadi, near the end of his life, visits the Buddha, and shows moving devotion and love for his teacher.

title: Kinh Kaṇṇakatthala
blurb: King Pasenadi questions the Buddha on miscellaneous matters: caste, omniscience, and the gods among them.

title: Kinh Brahmàyu
blurb: The oldest and most respected brahmin of the age sends a student to examine the Buddha, and he spends several months following his every move before reporting back. Convinced that the Buddha fulfills an ancient prophecy of the Great Man, the brahmin becomes his disciple.

title: Kinh Sela
blurb: A brahmanical ascetic named Keṇiya invites the entire Saṅgha for a meal. When the brahmin Sela sees what is happening, he visits the Buddha and expresses his delight in a moving series of devotional verses.

title: Kinh Assalāyana
blurb: A precocious brahmin student is encouraged against his wishes to challenge the Buddha on the question of caste. His reluctance turns out to be justified.

title: Kinh Ghotamukha
blurb: A brahmin denies that there is such a thing as a principled renunciate life, but Venerable Udena persuades him otherwise.

title: Kinh Cankì
blurb: The reputed brahmin Caṅkī goes with a large group to visit the Buddha, despite the reservations of other brahmins. A precocious student challenges the Buddha, affirming the validity of the Vedic scriptures. The Buddha gives a detailed explanation of how true understanding gradually emerges through spiritual education.

title: Kinh Esukàrì
blurb: A brahmin claims that one deserves service and privilege depending on caste, but the Buddha counters that it is conduct, not caste, that show a person’s worth.

title: Kinh Dhànanjàni
blurb: A corrupt tax-collector is redeemed by his encounter with Venerable Sāriputta.

title: Kinh Vāsaṭṭha
blurb: Two brahmin students ask the Buddha about what makes a brahmin: birth or deeds? the Buddha points out that, while the species of animals are determined by birth, for humans what matters is how you chose to live. This discourse anticipates the modern view that there are no such things as clearly defined racial differences among humans.

title: Kinh Subha
blurb: Working hard is not valuable in and of itself; what matters is the outcome. And just as in lay life, spiritual practice may or may not lead to fruitful results.

title: Kinh Sangàrava
blurb: Angered by the devotion of a brahmin lady, a brahmin visits the Buddha. He positions himself against traditionalists and rationalists, as someone whose teaching is based on direct experience.

title: Kinh Devadaha
blurb: The Buddha tackles a group of Jain ascetics, pressing them on their claim to be practicing to end all suffering by self-mortification. He points out a series of fallacies in their logic, and explains his own middle way.

title: Kinh Năm và Ba
blurb: A middle length version of the more famous Brahmajāla Sutta (DN1), this surveys a range of speculative views and dismisses them all.

title: Kinh Nghĩ như thế nào?
blurb: The Buddha teaches the monks to not dispute about the fundamental teachings, but to always strive for harmony.

title: Kinh Làng Sama
blurb: Hearing of the death of the Jain leader Nigaṇṭha Nātaputta, the Buddha encourages the Saṅgha to swiftly resolve any disputes. He lays down a series of seven methods for resolving disputes. These form the foundation for the monastic code.

title: Kinh Thiện tinh
blurb: Not all of those who claim to be awakened are genuine. The Buddha teaches how true spiritual progress depends on an irreversible letting go of the forces that lead to suffering.

title: Kinh Bất động lợi ích
blurb: Beginning with profound meditation absorption, the Buddha goes on to deeper and deeper levels, showing how insight on this basis leads to the detaching of consciousness from any form of rebirth.

title: Kinh Ganaka Moggallāna
blurb: The Buddha compares the training of an accountant with the step by step spiritual path of his followers. But even with such a well explained path, the Buddha can only show the way, and it is up to us to walk it.

title: Kinh Gopaka Moggallāna
blurb: Amid rising military tensions after the Buddha’s death, Venerable Ānanda is questioned about how the Saṅgha planned to continue in their teacher’s absence. As the Buddha refused to appoint a successor, the teaching and practice that he laid down become the teacher, and the Saṅgha resolves issues by consensus.

title: Ðại kinh Mãn nguyệt
blurb: On a lovely full moon night, one of the mendicants presents the Buddha with a series of questions that go to the heart of the teaching. But when he hears of the doctrine of not-self, another mendicant is unable to grasp the meaning.

title: Tiểu kinh Mãn nguyệt
blurb: A good person is able to understand a bad person, but not vice versa.

title: Kinh Bất đoạn
blurb: The Buddha describes in technical detail the process of insight of Venerable Sāriputta. Many ideas and terms in this text anticipate the Abhidhamma.

title: Kinh Sáu Thanh tịnh
blurb: If someone claims to be awakened, their claim should be interrogated with a detailed series of detailed questions. Only if they can answer them clearly should the claim be accepted.

title: Kinh Chân nhân
blurb: The Buddha explains that a truly good person does not disparage others or feel superior because of their attainment.

title: Kinh Nên hành trì, không nên hành trì
blurb: The Buddha sets up a framework on things to be cultivated or avoided, and Venerable Sāriputta volunteers to elaborate.

title: Kinh Ða giới
blurb: Beginning by praising a wise person, the Buddha goes on to explain that one becomes wise by inquiring into the elements, sense fields, dependent origination, and what is possible and impossible.

title: Kinh Thôn tiên
blurb: Reflecting on the changes that even geographical features undergo, the Buddha then recounts the names of sages of the past who have lived in Mount Isigili near Rājagaha.

title: Ðại kinh Bốn mươi
blurb: A discourse on the prerequisites of right samādhi that emphasizes the interrelationship and mutual support of all the factors of the eightfold path.

title:
Kinh Nhập tức, Xuất tức niệm
(Kinh Quán niệm hơi thở)
blurb: Surrounded by many well-practiced mendicants, the Buddha teaches mindfulness of breathing in detail, showing how it relates to the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

title: Kinh Thân hành niệm
blurb: This focuses on the first aspect of mindfulness meditation, the observation of the body. This set of practices, simple as they seem, have far-reaching benefits.

title: Kinh Hành sanh
blurb: The Buddha explains how one can make a wish to be reborn in different realms.

title: Kinh Tiểu không
blurb: The Buddha describes his own practice of the meditation on emptiness.

title: Kinh Ðại không
blurb: A group of mendicants have taken to socializing too much, so the Buddha teaches on the importance of seclusion in order to enter fully into emptiness.

title: Kinh Hy hữu vị tằng hữu pháp
blurb: Venerable Ānanda is invited by the Buddha to speak on the Buddha’s amazing qualities, and proceeds to list a series of apparently miraculous events accompanying his birth. The Buddha caps it off by explaining what he thinks is really amazing about himself.

title: Kinh Bạc-câu-la
blurb: Venerable Bakkula, regarded as the healthiest of the mendicants, explains to an old friend his strict and austere practice. The unusual form of this discourse suggests it was added to the canon some time after the Buddha’s death.

title: Kinh Ðiều ngự địa
blurb: A young monk is unable to persuade a prince of the blessings of peace of mind. The Buddha offers similes based on training an elephant that would have been successful, as this was a field the prince was familiar with.

title: Kinh Phù-di
blurb: Success in the spiritual life does not depend on any vows you may or may not make, but on whether you practice well.

title: Kinh A-na-luật
blurb: A lay person becomes confused when encouraged to develop the “limitless” and “expansive” liberations, and asks Venerable Anuruddha to explain whether they are the same or different.

title: Kinh Tùy phiền não
blurb: A second discourse set at the quarrel of Kosambi, this depicts the Buddha, having failed to achieve reconciliation between the disputing mendicants, leaving the monastery. He spends time in the wilderness before encountering an inspiring community of practicing monks. There he discusses in detail obstacles to meditation that he encountered before awakening.

title: Kinh Hiền Ngu
blurb: A fool suffers both in this life and the next, while the astute benefits in both respects.

title: Kinh Thiên sứ
blurb: Expanding on the previous, this discourse contains the most detailed descriptions of the horrors of hell.

title: Kinh Nhất dạ hiền giả
blurb: This discourse opens with a short but powerful set of verses extolling the benefits of insight into the here and now, followed by an explanation.

title: Kinh A-nan Nhất dạ hiền giả
blurb: The same discourse as MN 131, but spoken by Venerable Ānanda.

title: Kinh Ðại Ca-chiên-diên Nhất dạ hiền giả
blurb: The verses from MN 131 are explained in a different way by Venerable Mahakaccāna.

title: Kinh Lomasakangiya Nhất dạ hiền giả
blurb: A monk who does not know the verses from MN 131 is encouraged by a deity to learn them.

title: Tiểu kinh Nghiệp phân biệt
blurb: The Buddha explains to a brahmin how your deeds in past lives affect you in this life.

title: Ðại kinh Nghiệp phân biệt
blurb: Confronted with an overly simplistic version of his own teachings, the Buddha emphasizes the often overlooked nuances and qualifications in how karma plays out.

title: Kinh Phân biệt sáu xứ
blurb: A detailed analysis of the six senses and the relation to emotional and cognitive processes.

title: Kinh Tổng thuyết và Biệt thuyết
blurb: The Buddha gives a brief and enigmatic statement on the ways consciousness may become attached. Venerable Mahākaccāna is invited by the mendicants to draw out the implications.

title: Kinh Vô tránh phân biệt
blurb: Achieving peace is no simple matter. The Buddha explains how to avoid conflict through contentment, right speech, understanding pleasure, and not insisting on local conventions.

title: Kinh Giới phân biệt
blurb: While staying overnight in a potter’s workshop, the Buddha has a chance encounter with a monk who does not recognize him. They have a long and profound discussion based on the four elements. This is one of the most insightful and moving discourses in the canon.

title: Kinh Phân biệt về Sự thật
blurb: Expanding on the Buddha’s first sermon, Venerable Sāriputta gives a detailed explanation of the four noble truths.

title: Kinh Phân biệt cúng dường
blurb: When his step-mother Mahāpajāpatī wishes to offer him a robe for his personal use, the Buddha encourages her to offer it to the entire Saṅgha instead. He goes on to explain that the best kind of offering to the Saṅgha is one given to the dual community of monks and nuns, headed by the Buddha.

title: Kinh Giáo giới Cấp Cô Ðộc
blurb: As the great lay disciple Anāthapiṇḍika lies dying, Venerable Sāriputta visits him and gives a powerful teaching on non-attachment.

title: Kinh Giáo giới Channa
blurb: The monk Channa is suffering a painful terminal illness and wishes to take his own life.

title: Kinh Giáo giới Phú-lâu-na
blurb: On the eve of his departure to a distant country, full of wild and unpredictable people, Venerable Puṇṇa is asked by the Buddha how he would respond if attacked there.

title: Kinh Giáo giới Nandaka
blurb: When asked to teach the nuns, Venerable Nandaka proceeds by inviting them to engage with his discourse and ask if there is anything that needs further explanation.

title: Tiểu kinh Giáo giới La-hầu-la
blurb: The Buddha takes Rāhula with him to a secluded spot in order to lead him on to liberation.

title: Kinh Sáu sáu
blurb: The Buddha analyzes the six senses from six perspectives, and demonstrates the emptiness of all of them.

title: Ðại kinh Sáu xứ
blurb: Explains how insight into the six senses is integrated with the eightfold path and leads to liberation.

title: Kinh Nói cho dân Nagaravinda
blurb: In discussion with a group of householders, the Buddha helps them to distinguish those spiritual practitioners who are truly worthy of respect.

title: Kinh Khất thực thanh tịnh
blurb: The Buddha notices Venerable Sāriputta’s glowing complexion, which is the result of his deep meditation. He then presents a series of reflections by which a mendicant can be sure that they are worthy of their alms-food.

title: Kinh Căn tu tập
blurb: A brahmin teacher advocates that purification of the senses consists in simply avoiding seeing and hearing things. The Buddha explains that it is not about avoiding sense experience, but understanding it and learning to not be affected by sense experience.

title: Rừng Núi
blurb: Spiritual practitioners have clear complexions, despite their simple life.

title: Bộc Lưu
blurb: The Buddha crossed the flood of suffering by neither standing nor swimming.

title: Vườn Hoan Hỷ
blurb: Even the divine Garden of Delight is impermanent.

title: Vui Thích
blurb: We think our attachments bring us happiness, but they really bring sorrow.

title: Không Ai Bằng Con
blurb: Like many of these discourses, here the Buddha repeats a god’s verses with a subtle twist towards the Dhamma.

title: Giai Cấp Sát Ðế Lỵ
blurb: A god’s worldly values are improved by the Buddha’s version.

title: Tiếng Ðộng Rừng Sâu (hay Thân tịch tịnh)
blurb: The quiet murmuring of the jungle can be scary—but not to the Buddha.

title: Ngủ Gục, Biếng Nhác
blurb: Laziness is an obstruction to the path.

title: Khó Làm (hay Con rùa)
blurb: Life is hard for an unrestrained ascetic; they should draw in their thoughts like a tortoise.

title: Tàm Quý
blurb: Does anyone have a sense of conscience and shame?

title: Am Tranh
blurb: Do you have a little hut and a little nest—or are you free?

title: Samiddhi
blurb: A deity tries to tempt a monk to first enjoy sensual pleasures and then go forth.

title: Giải Thoát
blurb: Freedom comes when we end attachment to rebirth.

title: Kiếm:
blurb: A mendicant should live as if their head was on fire.

title: Xúc Chạm
blurb: The evil you do hurts yourself.

title: Triền Phược
blurb: This generation is all tangled up like a nest of matted hair. But who can unravel the tangle?

title: Chế Ngự Tâm
blurb: One should rein in the mind, but only from that which is evil.

title: Vị A-La-Hán
blurb: If a perfected one has gone beyond all sense of self, would they still refer to themselves as “I”?

title: Ánh Sáng
blurb: How many lights are there that light up the world?

title: Nước Chảy
blurb: The stream of rebirth stops flowing when name and form ceases.

title: Giàu Lớn
blurb: Even the rich are full of greed for more—is there anyone free of greed?

title: Bốn Bánh Xe
blurb: A riddle on the topic of escape.

title: Con Sơn Dương
blurb: The Buddha is asked how to find release from suffering.

title: Ðưa Ðến Ðoạn Tận -
blurb: Life is short, so we should drop the world’s bait.

title: Với Người Thiện
blurb: A series of deities give verses praising association with the good, and the Buddha gives his own response.

title: Xan Tham
blurb: A series of deities give verses praising generosity, and the Buddha gives his own response.

title: Lành Thay
blurb: A series of deities give verses praising generosity, and the Buddha gives his own response, saying that practice of the Dhamma goes beyond this.

title: Chúng Không Phải
blurb: Two deities exchange verses with the Buddha on how sensual pleasures give rise to suffering.

title: Hiềm Trách Thiên
blurb: Some deities come to find fault with the Buddha. He responds to their critique, which stimulates a further discussion on wrong-doing and forgiveness.

title: Lòng Tin
blurb: A series of Satullapa gods address the Buddha with verses on various topics. The identifications of the verses in this unclear, and comparison with the Chinese parallels suggests the Pali may have suffered textual loss.

title: Tụ Hội
blurb: A vast congregation of deities assembles to see the Buddha and the Saṅgha at Kapilavatthu.

title: Miếng Ðá Vụn
blurb: A series of deities praise the Buddha’s resilience and composure when his foot is injured by a stone.

title: Con Gái Của Pajjuna
blurb: A goddess identifying herself as Kokanadā claims to confirm with her own experience the Buddha’s teachings on karma.

title: Con Gái Của Pajjuna
blurb: A goddess identified as Kokanada, possibly the sister of the previous, sums up the teaching in a pithy verse.

title: Thời Gian Trôi Qua
blurb: Time flies, so we should drop the world’s bait.

title: Thiêu Cháy
blurb: A deity recites to the Buddha some verses

title: Cho Gì?
blurb: Different kinds of gifts have different purposes.

title: Ðồ Ăn
blurb: Gods and humans love to eat, so what kind of being does not like food?

title: Một Căn Rễ
blurb: A single verse in the form of a Dhamma riddle.

title: Bậc Hoàn Toàn
blurb: A verse in praise of the Buddha.

title: Thiên Nữ
blurb: To escape from the Forest of Delusion, one needs the vehicle of the Dhamma.

title: Trồng Rừng
blurb: For those who give the gift of a monastery, merit always grows.

title: Kỳ Viên
blurb: Verses in praise of the Jetavana monastery, the Dhamma, and venerable Sāriputta, apparently spoken by the deity Anāthapiṇḍika.

title: Xan Tham
blurb: The Buddha is asked about the future destiny of people who are stingy and those who are generous.

title: Thợ Ðồ Gốm
blurb: Ghaṭīkāra, a disciple of the former Buddha Kassapa, comes to the Buddha and speaks of his past life, and of the attainments of six friends.

title: Bao Nhiêu Phải Cắt Ðoạn.
blurb: A cryptic set of questions, which the Buddha answers equally cryptically.

title: Già
blurb: Morality is good even in old age.

title: Không Già
blurb: Morality is good when it doesn’t decay.

title: Bạn
blurb: Things that are friends in this life and the next.

title: Cơ Sở
blurb: What is it that sustains various beings? Unusually, this verse lacks a “Dhamma” counterpart.

title: Sanh Nhân
blurb: A person is created by craving and fears suffering.

title: Sanh Nhân
blurb: A person is created by craving and is not freed from suffering

title: Sanh Nhân
blurb: A person is created by craving and their destiny is shaped by their deeds.

title: Phi Ðạo
blurb: What is the wrong path?

title: Người Bạn
blurb: A person’s true companion is their faith.

title: Người Thi Sĩ
blurb: A pair of verses on the nature of poetry, and lacking a Dhamma counterpart.

title: Tỉnh Giác
blurb: How many are awake while others are asleep?

title: Danh
blurb: “Name” weighs everything down.

title: Tâm
blurb: The mind leads the world around and controls it all.

title: Khát Ái
blurb: The mind leads the world around and craving controls it.

title: Kiết Sử
blurb: The world is fettered by craving.

title: Triền Phược
blurb: The world is bound by craving.

title: Bị Áp Ðảo
blurb: The world is afflicted with death and old age, and burning with desire.

title: Bị Treo Cột
blurb: The world is caught by craving and built on suffering.

title: Bị Ðóng Kín
blurb: The world is shut in by death.

title: Ước Muốn
blurb: The world is bound by desire.

title: Ðời (Thế gian)
blurb: A Dhamma riddle whose answer, enigmatically, is “six”.

title: Không Liễu Tri
blurb: Those who comprehend the teachings live smooth amid the rough.

title: Ðoạn Sát
blurb: The killing of anger is the only killing praised by the noble ones.

title: Cỗ Xe
blurb: What is the sign or token of a chariot, a fire, a nation, and a woman?

title: Tài Sản
blurb: A series of questions on what is best.

title: Mưa
blurb: A series of questions asked by one deity, answered by another, and then given a better answer by the Buddha.

title: Khủng Bố
blurb: Why is it that, though the path has been taught, people still fear?

title: Không Già
blurb: A series of questions on the path.

title: Tôn Chủ
blurb: A series of questions on diverse matters.

title: Dục
blurb: What is it that one should not give away?

title: Lương Thực
blurb: A series of questions on diverse topics.

title: Chớp
blurb: A series of questions on diverse topics.

title: Mê Loạn
blurb: Those who are unconfused live smooth amid the rough.

title: Không Tranh Luận
blurb: A series of questions on diverse kinds of people

title: Mong Muốn Kiêu Mạn
blurb: Unless you give up conceit you’ll be trapped in the domain of Death.

title: Suriya: (Nhật Thiên tử)
blurb: In a parable of a solar eclipse, the sun god Suriya is swallowed by the demon lord Rāhu. Suriya appeals to the Buddha, who tells Rāhu to let go. This sutta is recited as a protection verse.

title: Kassapa—Ca-diếp
blurb: A deity named Kassapa comes to the Buddha and speaks of the training of a mendicant in seclusion and right speech.

title: Candimasa
blurb: The deity Candimasa says that those who practice absorption will surely find escape. The Buddha adds that they must also be diligent and discard flaws.

title: Veṇḍu
blurb: The deity Veṇhu celebrates the joy of those who follow the Buddha’s teaching. The Buddha affirms that such will escape death. Veṇhu is the Pali spelling of Sanskrit Viṣṇu, and this marks a rare appearance of a god of this name in the early texts.

title: Diighalatthi
blurb: Dīghalaṭṭhi the god comes to the Buddha at Rājagaha and praises a mendicant who is a meditator.

title: Nandana
blurb: The deity Nandana asks the Buddha who is virtuous, wise, beyond suffering, worshiped by the gods themselves. The Buddha replies that such a person is an arahant.

title: Candana: Chiên Ðàn
blurb: Candana asks who crosses the flood. The Buddha replies that it is one who is virtuous , wise, peaceful, and beyond attachment to rebirth.

title: Sudatta (Tu-đạt-đa)
blurb: The deity Vasudatta says that a mendicant should live like their hair is on fire so as to give up lust. The Buddha changes his verse to emphasize giving up attachment to self.

title: Subrahmà
blurb: Subrahmā the god asks for the escape from fear. The Buddha says there is no escape from fear without letting go of everything.

title: Kakudha
blurb: At Sāketa the god Kakudha asks the Buddha if he delights or sorrows. The Buddha replies that since he has no attachments he neither delights nor sorrows.

title: Uttara
blurb: The god Uttara speaks of the transience of life, saying one should do good to be reborn in a happy future life. The Buddha replies that one should let go attachment.

title: Anāthapiṇḍika: Cấp Cô Ðộc
blurb: A deity who had been the Buddha’s supporter Anāthapiṇḍika in his former life comes to Buddha and speaks verses in celebration of the Jeta’s Grove monastery—which he had offered for the Buddha’s use—good deeds, the Dhamma, and Venerable Sāriputta.

title: Kassapa
blurb: The deity Kassapa speaks of how a mendicant should be a meditator, peaceful and free.

title: Siva
blurb: The deity Siva says one should associate only with the good, and this will lead to happiness. The Buddha adds that associating with the good leads to the end of suffering. Siva is the Pali spelling of Sanskrit Śiva, and this marks a rare appearance of a god of this name in the early texts.

title: Khemā
blurb: The deity Khema utters a series of verses in praise of good deeds. The Buddha responds with a simile for someone who departs the path of the good.

title: Serì
blurb: The deity Serī speaks of how everyone loves food., to which the Buddha responds with verses in praise of giving. Serī speaks of his own generosity in a past life.

title: Ghatìkara
blurb: The deity Ghaṭīkāra speaks of the seven mendicants reborn in the Aviha realm. The sutta is similar to SN 1.50.

title: Jantu
blurb: Some monks in Kosala fell into negligence, and were admonished by the deity Jantu.

title: Rohita
blurb: Rohitassa asks the Buddha if it is possible to reach the end of the world by traveling. The Buddha says no; and Rohitassa tells of how in a past life as a seer he had tried to accomplish this very feat and failed. The Buddha says the end of the world is found in this body.

title: Nanda:
blurb: Nanda speaks of the transience of life, saying one should do good to be reborn in a happy future life. The Buddha replies that one should let go attachment.

title: Nandivisàla:
blurb: The god Nandivisāla gives an elaborate metaphor for the body, and asks how to escape from it.

title: Susima
blurb: The Buddha asks Ānanda if he likes Sāriputta, and when he replies that he does, the god Susīma and his assembly appear, rejoicing in Sāriputta’s praises, and radiating in lustrous colors.

title: Các Ngoại Ðạo Sư
blurb: A series of deities who had formerly been ascetics in the non-Buddhist sects came to the Buddha, speaking verses in praise—or occasional criticism—of their former teachers

title: Māgha
blurb: The god Māgha asks the Buddha about what one should slay in order to sleep well and be without sorrow.

title: Màgadha
blurb: The deity Māgadha asks the Buddha how many sources of light there are in the world. The Buddha speaks of five lights, but the Buddha is the best of them.

title: Dàmali
blurb: Dāmali the god suggests that a true brahmin must strive to abandon desire. The Buddha disagrees, saying that a true holy one has already completed their work.

title: Kàmada
blurb: The deity Kāmada addresses the Buddha with a series of cryptic statements lamenting the difficulty of spiritual practice. The Buddha agrees, but points out that true practitioners do it even though it’s hard.

title: Pancàlacanda
blurb: Pañcālacaṇḍa praises the Buddha for finding the opening amid the confinement of the world. But the Buddha affirms that anyone with mindfulness and stillness may find such an escape.

title: Tàyana
blurb: Tāyana, a deity who was in a past life was a leader of a non-Buddhist sect, speaks a series of verses in praise of strenuous exertion and discipline. These famous verses are commonly recited by Theravadin monks.

title: Candima
blurb: In a parable of a lunar eclipse, the moon god Candimā is swallowed by the demon lord Rāhu. Candimā appeals to the Buddha, who tells Rāhu to let go. This sutta is recited as a protection verse.

title: Triền Phược
blurb: When many people are put in chains by Pasenadi, the matter is reported to the Buddha.

title: Tuổi Trẻ
blurb: King Pasenadi meets the Buddha for the first time. He wonders how the Buddha can claim to be awakened when he is still so young. The Buddha teaches him four things that should not be looked down on for their youth.

title: Bện Tóc
blurb: A diverse group of ascetics passes by, and Pasenadi asks the Buddha if any of them are perfected ones. The Buddha says it is not easy for one such as Pasenadi to judge the spiritual achievements of others. Pasenadi reveals that the men are, in fact, his spies.

title: Năm Vua
blurb: Five kings including Pasenadi are enjoying themselves and wonder which of the senses affords the highest pleasure. They ask the Buddha, who replies that it is subjective, depending on a persons preferences. Inspired, the laymen Candanaṅgalika offers a verse in praise of the Buddha.

title: Ðại Thực: Ăn nhiều
blurb: In what is probably the world’s first weight loss diet, when Pasenadi shows up overweight and out of breath, the Buddha advises him to cut down his eating. He gives a verse to one of the king’s attendants, and asks him to recite it whenever the king is eating.

title: Hai Lời Nói Về Chiến Tranh
blurb: Pasenadi loses a battle against his nephew King Ajātasattu of Magadha.

title: Dutiyasaṅgāmasutta
blurb: In a battle subsequent to SN 3.14, Pasenadi defeats Ajātasattu and takes him prisoner. Acting compassionately, he confiscates Ajātasattu’s military assets but releases him alive.

title: Người Con Gái
blurb: Pasenadi is disappointed to hear that Queen Mallikā has given birth to a daughter. But the Buddha consoles him, saying a woman may turn out better than a man.

title: Không Phóng Dật
blurb: Pasenadi asks the Buddha if there is one thing that secures benefit both in this life and the next.

title: Không Phóng Dật
blurb: In answer to Pasenadi’s praise of good friendship, the Buddha recounts an earlier conversation with Ānanda on the topic. He then goes on to say that when one has good friends, it is important to develop diligence.

title: Không Con
blurb: A wealthy man dies childless, having not enjoyed his riches. The Buddha says that wealth should be properly enjoyed and shared.

title: Không Có Con
blurb: A wealthy man dies childless, having not enjoyed his riches. The Buddha tells of how in the time of a solitary Buddha of the past named Tagarasikhī, a householder made an offering but later regretted it.

title: Người
blurb: Pasenadi asks of the things that cause suffering when they arise in oneself.

title: Người
blurb: The Buddha teaches Pasenadi of four kinds of person, going from dark to dark, dark to light, light to dark, and light to light.

title: Tổ Mẫu
blurb: Pasenadi laments the death of his aged grandmother.

title: Thế Gian
blurb: How many things give rise to suffering in oneself?

title: Cung Thuật
blurb: “Where should I give” and “Where is a gift is most fruitful” are two different questions.

title: Ví Dụ Hòn Núi
blurb: Old age and death roll in upon all like mountains approaching from the four directions, crushing all in their path

title: Vua
blurb: Pasenadi asks if anything that is born can escape from old age and death.

title: Thân Ái
blurb: Reporting on a reflection that arose while on retreat, Pasenadi says that those who do bad deeds treat themselves as enemy. The Buddha expresses his agreement in verse.

title: Tự Bảo Hộ
blurb: Even if protected by an entire army, one who does bad deeds is still unprotected.

title: Thiểu Số
blurb: There are few in the world who do not become negligent and complacent once they obtain material luxuries.

title: Xử Kiện
blurb: Pasenadi laments how in his judgment hall he sees people lying all the time for the sake of sensual pleasures.

title: Mallikà: Mạt-lỵ
blurb: Pasandi asks Queen Mallikā who is most dear. They both agree that the one most dear is oneself, and the Buddha agrees.

title: Tế Ðàn
blurb: A great sacrifice involving the slaughter of many animals was being prepared for King Pasenadi. The Buddha condemns such sacrifices and says a fruitful sacrifice involves a blameless and harmless offering.

title: Tuổi Thọ
blurb: Though the Buddha says that life is short, Māra says it is long.

title: Khổ Hạnh Và Nghiệp
blurb: Māra accuses the Buddha of having abandoned the path of true austerity.

title: Hòn Ðá
blurb: Māra smashes boulders in an attempt to scare the Buddha.

title: Con Sư Tử
blurb: Māra criticizes the Buddha for his lion’s roar, asserting that the Buddha is not in fact peerless.

title: Phiến Ðá
blurb: The Buddha rests after being struck by stone splinters, and Māra criticizes him for being lazy.

title: Tương Ưng Thích Nghi
blurb: Māra discourages the Buddha from teaching, warning him that he will become corrupted by favoritism.

title: Ý
blurb: Māra threatens the Buddha with a “mental snare” in the sky.

title: Bình Bát
blurb: While the mendicants are listening to the teachings, Māra takes the form of an ox and looks as if he will break their almsbowls.

title: Xứ
blurb: While the mendicants are listening to the teachings, Māra makes an awful roar to distract them.

title: Ðoàn Thực
blurb: Māra ensures that the Buddha fails to get alms, but the Buddha is happy to feed on joy.

title: Người Nông Phu
blurb: While the mendicants are listening to the teachings, Māra takes the form of a farmer looking for lost oxen and addresses the Buddha.

title: Thống Trị
blurb: The Buddha wonders whether it is possible to rule justly, without violence. Māra appears and encourages the Buddha to pursue such a path.

title: Con Voi
blurb: Māra manifests before the Buddha in the form of a ferocious elephant in order to scare him.

title: Ða Số
blurb: Māra approaches some young mendicants as an old brahmin, and tries to tempt them with talk of the pleasures of youth.

title: Samiddhi
blurb: Māra repeatedly pesters the monk Samiddhi when he is on retreat. The Buddha encourages him, until eventually Samiddhi is able to recognize Māra for himself.

title: Godhika
blurb: Venerable Godhika finds himself repeatedly falling away from his meditation attainments due to severe illness. Eventually he considers suicide, and Māra tries to get the Buddha to deter him. But the Buddha says Godhika has already attained awakening and has died blamelessly.

title: Bảy Năm
blurb: Māra has tried to distract the Buddha for seven years without success. He laments his failure with the similes of a crab whose limbs are smashed by a group of children, and a crow who tried to eat a stone.

title: Những Người Con Gái
blurb: Depressed, Māra laments to his three daughters of his failure to distract the Buddha. So they take on the task themselves, and assume a variety of sensuous forms to tempt him. But they fail too, and Māra castigates them for being so presumptuous

title: Tịnh
blurb: Māra tries to scare the Buddha by taking on shifting forms both beautiful and hideous.

title: Bẫy Sập
blurb: When the Buddha explains to the mendicants how he realized freedom, Māra claims he is still trapped.

title: Bẫy Sập
blurb: When the Buddha explains to the mendicants how he has realized freedom, and so have his mendicant followers, Māra claims he is still trapped.

title: Con Rắn
blurb: Māra manifests as a huge serpent, but the Buddha is unshaken.

title: Thụy Miên
blurb: After meditating all night, the Buddha lies down to sleep at dawn, and Māra scolds him for being lazy.

title: Hoan Hỷ
blurb: The Buddha and Māra exchange verses on whether attachments are a source of delight or suffering.

title: Tuổi Thọ
blurb: Though the Buddha says that life is short, Māra says it is long.

title: Vajirà
blurb: Māra asks the nun Vajirā about who has created this being. Recognizing him, she points out that the word “being” is nothing more than a convention used to designate the aggregates, just as the word “cart” is used when the parts are assembled

title: Alavikhà
blurb: The nun Āḷavikā has entered the Dark Wood seeking seclusion when Māra comes to threaten her, claiming there is no escape and no point in seclusion. She recognizes him instantly and dismisses his taunts, asserting that she is beyond his control.

title: Somà
blurb: When meditating in the Dark Wood, the nun Somā is taunted by Māra, who claims that a mere woman can never see the subtle truth. She rejects him, stating that gender does not matter when one is perceiving deep truths, and telling Māra to go see those still attached to gender.

title: Gotamì
blurb: Māra taunts the nun Kisāgotamī, alleging she is mourning sons and longing for a man. She rejects him, stating that she has no need for men, as she has destroyed the mass of darkness and conquered the army of Death.

title: Vijayà
blurb: Māra comes to the nun Vijayā in the form of a handsome youth and tries to tempt her from her path. But she rejects sensual pleasures, as she delights in subtle meditation and has ended ignorance.

title: Uppalavannà
blurb: Uppalavaṇṇā is rebuked by Māra, who says a beautiful woman like her should fear rogues when alone in the forest. However, she dismisses such fears, saying she can use her psychic powers to defeat thousands of rogues like him.

title: Càlà
blurb: Māra asks the nun Cālā why she disapproves of rebith. She replies that it necessarily entails suffering.

title: Upacàlà
blurb: Māra asks the nun Upacālā where she wishes to be reborn. But as the world everywhere is burning, she rejects all forms of rebirth.

title: Sisupacàlà
blurb: Māra asks the nun Sīsupacālā whose teaching she believes in. She replies that she rejects the various sectarians and follows the Buddha, as his teachings lead to freedom.

title: Selà
blurb: Māra asks the nun Selā about who has created this “puppet”, i.e. the form that has been reincarnated. She replies that there is no creator, but it arises as a result of conditions, like the growing of a seed in a field.

title: Kokālika
blurb: Kokālika goes to the Buddha and criticizes Sāriputta and Moggallāna. But having deliberately slandered such great monks, he dies and Brahmā Sahampati informs the Buddha he has been reborn in hell. The Buddha gives a memorable simile of the length of life in hell.

title: Thỉnh Cầu
blurb: After his awakening, the Buddha hesitated to teach, thinking that the Dhamma is too subtle for people to understand. But the high divinity Brahmā Sahampati appears and encourages him to teach, pointing out that there are some with “little dust in their eyes” who will understand.

title: Sanankumāra—Thường Ðồng tử
blurb: Brahmā Sanaṅkumāra appears to the Buddha and asserts that the aristocrat or khattiya is the best caste, but the Buddha is the best of people.

title: Devadatta
blurb: Brahmā Sahampati, referring to Devadatta, points out that honors destroy a scoundrel.

title: Andhakavinda
blurb: Brahmā Sahampati appears to the Buddha and speaks in praise of the renunciates staying fearless in the deep forest, and celebrates the many who have found freedom.

title: Arunavàti
blurb: The Buddha tells a story of the past Buddha Sikhī and his disciple Abhibhū. They visit a brahmā realm where they perform many astounding feats and give teachings.

title: Parinibhàna—Bát-Niết-Bàn
blurb: After the Buddha became finally extinguished, Brahmā Sahampati led a series of distinguished beings who uttered verses in commemoration

title: Cung Kính.
blurb: After his awakening, the Buddha reflects that one should live with reverence; but who is he to revere, since he is fully awakened? He realizes that he should live revering the Dhamma. Brahmā Sahampati appears and agrees with him, saying that this is how all Buddhas of past and future live too.

title: Phạm Thiên.
blurb: Brahmā Sahampati appears before a woman who is a devotee of his, and tells her to offer food instead to her son, a Buddhist monk, as Brahmās don’t eat the food she offers.

title: Phạm Thiên Baka
blurb: Baka the Brahmā conceives the wrong view that his status is permanent and imperishable. The Buddha goes to dissuade him, and they have an exchange in verse, with the Buddha telling Baka of his past lives.

title: Tà Kiến Khác
blurb: An unnamed brahmā god thinks to himself that he is so powerful no asectic can approach him. The Buddha goes straight to his realm and appears wrapped in flame above his head. Mahāmoggallāna and several other disciples follow him. The brahmā and his retinue are sutiably impressed.

title: Phóng Dật
